subject: RE: [junit] Re: How to run same testcase with 20 different   arg-values to test diff. results
msgSnippet: ... No-one can argue with personal preference. I just wouldn t do it that way. If I have 10 tests, I want JUnit to say 10 runs . I find no compelling reason
messageBody:
>So said Andrew McDonagh on 2003-07-24 --------------------
>
>I understand your reasoning, but from a personal point of view, I'd prefer
>to see the one physical test fail during one of the logical tests.

No-one can argue with personal preference. I just wouldn't do it that way. If I have 10 tests, I want JUnit to say "10 runs". I find no compelling reason to do otherwise. If you have one, then by all means, use it.

>I see
>the logical tests as just a series of asserts within the same testcase, but
>refactored to remove 'some' duplication.
>
>eg.
>
>public void testRangeValues() {
> assertEquals(Integer.minValue, Integer.minValue);
> assertEquals(Integer.maxValue, Integer.maxValue);
> assertEquals(new Integer(0), new Integer(0));
>}
>
>becomes...
>
>public void testRangeValues() {
> testTwoIntegers(Integer.minValue, Integer.minValue);
> testTwoIntegers(Integer.maxValue, Integer.maxValue);
> testTwoIntegers(new Integer(0), new Integer(0));
>}

This doesn't remove duplication; it only reveals intent. My suggestion removes the duplication (as would a simple loop in this case). It's an important distinction.

>Note: This is a simplistic example...obviously we'd be doing more than
>testing two integers - to answer the original question.

I don't suppose it matters what the tests actually do for the purposes of this conversation; just that we want to run the same test for n sets of data.

Take care.
